title: Richard Nixon
deleted: Before Nixon had become president, the United States had a good relationship with both India and Pakistan at various times. The relations between USSR and India had deepened in the 1960s, leaving Nixon's administration worried since it believed they could offer India military assistance as well during the time of [[Bangladesh Liberation War]]. The Soviets had stated that they would [[United Nations Security Council veto power|veto]] any criticism of [[United Nations]] regarding its intervention in the war. Nixon favored Pakistan over India especially after its [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Yahya Khan]] helped in organizing a summit with China. HE also personally disliked [[Indian Prime Minister]] [[Indira Gandhi]] and saw Yahya as a bulwark against expansion of USSR's influence in South Asia.<ref>https://www.google.com/books/edition/Balancing_Act_how_Nixon_Went_to_China_an/qOOEH2GBUcUC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=nixon+india&pg=PA144&printsec=frontcover</ref>

Kissinger himself was impressed by Pakistan's brutal suppression of rebellion in [[East Pakistan]] and believed it could be successful. Nixon too was happy that Pakistan's control of Bangladesh was stable and stated a smaller force can defeat a larger nation any time if they're greatly disciplined, reminding Kissinger about the [[Spanish colonization of the Americas]] and [[British colonisation of India]]. He wanted to make sure that Pakistan wasn't split into two and sympathized with Yahya Khan, stating it was difficult for anyone to rule over Bangladesh. Though Nixon and Kissinger knew of [[Pakistan Army]]'s brutality on Bengalis, both would mock [[Archer Blood]] for complaining about its genocidal actions there and didn't want to upset Pakistan's government by criticizing its actions openly. Nixon stated that it was better for them to stay out of it just like in the [[Nigerian Civil War]], stating, "I don't like it, but I didn't like shooting [[Biafrans]] either."<ref>https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Blood_Telegram/yjJjDwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=I+don%27t+like+it,+but+I+didn%27t+like+shooting+Biafrans+either&pg=PP83&printsec=frontcover</ref>

Nixon did wish to end the Pakistani civil war though, and worked towards it while preventing Pakistan from being split. He also believed that crticizing yahya in public, wound ensure he would be toppled from power in Pakistan and it could also threaten the upcoming summit in China. [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] [[Sadruddin Aga Khan]] told him that Yahya was under political pressures to crack down on Bengali rebels. He told Pakistan's leaders that he wished for the war to end, while also telling Yahya to improve live of Bengalis by initiating reforms, stooping the military operation and handing over power to a democratic government. Yahya listened to his advice and the United States also donated $1 million in order to help the refugees. Nixon later in discussion with [[Agha Hilaly]], [[Pakistan's Ambassador to the United State]], encouraged the Pakistan government to improve the situation in East Pakistan, in order to prevent a refugee exodus.<ref>https://www.google.com/books/edition/Balancing_Act_how_Nixon_Went_to_China_an/qOOEH2GBUcUC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=nixon+india&pg=PA145&printsec=frontcover</ref>
